content: @WG-async-sprint-planning reminder, we have a sprint planning meeting in 1 hour
@WG-async-sprint-planning :wave: hey everyone

Our agenda for today is the same as always:

  • Sprint retrospective
  • Assign [polish issues]
  • Identify sprint goals
before diving into the retrospective, let's take some time to update the sprint doc for the last sprint
wave
I think async fundamentals update is done, at least
Okay, as people wrap up updates we can transition into retrospective
Sprint retrospective
How did the last sprint go?
It was the first one we've done that was 4 weeks long, I'm curious to know how that worked for people
I was not able to do any polish issues
but that has more to do with .. other distracting events than anything else :)
The longer sprint and the US holiday in the middle made it a weird sprint.
I did notice the longer period; I think i kind of liked it in some sense, but it also felt like we were a bit more "aimless" by the end?
I got the generator captures PR posted! But I pretty much forgot about the other things I planned to do.
yeah I have mixed feelings. On the one hand, I sort of needed the longer sprint, due to other things going on concurrently
I also didn't look at polish issues, but I made good progress on the interoperability stuff - we are up and running , pretty much
oh, and I owe you more reviews
one thing I am noticing btw
but I also worry that maybe I needed the two-week cadence to keep myself honest

nikomatsakis said:

oh, and I oh you more reviews

Take your time, I know you have a lot of other things to do.
we don't have a dedicated time for "updates" on progress, right?
I did make progress on my polish issue though. “Progress” in a sort of two-steps forward, one step backward fashion.

eholk said:

Take your time, I know you have a lot of other things to do.

it's dangerous to tell me that :)

nikomatsakis said:

we don't have a dedicated time for "updates" on progress, right?

I feel like it'd be cool if we tried to write up a blog post every few months or something
I'm thinking the tradeoff with the longer sprint is it is a bit of a "longer leash" which can lead to more open ended exploration, but less focus on concrete goals
I was thinking about a kind of "looking over the last year" post, talking about what we learned, what we've done, etc
ah, yeah, I was wanting to write a blog post as we started doing these sprints and never did
Overall I like the two week sprint better, but I think to do a fair comparison we'd need to try four weeks in January or February.
I made progress on my polish issue, but didn't complete all the goals I had on it for the sprint
@triagebot end-topic shall we move on?

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.

nikomatsakis said:

I was thinking about a kind of "looking over the last year" post, talking about what we learned, what we've done, etc

I meant to say, I agree this is a good idea. Maybe a goal for the coming sprint :)

I got through everything that was "just hack on your tiny crate", but got more stuck on things that required interacting with rustc, including the polish tickets (thanks for the reviews btw, but I think we might need to do something about having a pool of reviewers to ensure faster turn arounds)

I think we might need to do something about having a pool of reviewers to ensure faster turn arounds

I've noticed that I have been lugging around a polish ticket for several sprints even though I've had the PR up for a while, so I end up taking new polish tickets but not being able to close the previous ones, which is giving me some anguish :weary:
hmm yeah, I've noticed that the sprint goals don't really incentivize doing reviews for other people :)
hmm
(also, as we are all aware, the next several weeks are going to be a black hole of communication for a lot of people, we need to account for that as well)
I wonder how much that is a problem across the project as a whole
also, if I see one that's stalled but not assigned to me it's hard to know whether it would be helpful for me to review or not
(though I suppose that has a straightforward solution of pinging the author/reviewer.. the bigger blocker is prioritizing spending time on reviews)

What drives reviews. “oh I want to see this land for my own sake”, or “oh that person pinged me, I will indeed review this for them.” and beyond that …? “Oh, I want to see the list of open PR’s decrease in size” ?

I think that if a PR is stalled on review because of me, it's usually because I want to take a deeper look at it, having someone else do a pass is actually helpful, if for nothing else to reduce the number of things I need to look at and to give some feedback to the PR author
honestly I don’t know what large project has this problem solved..

“Oh, I want to see the list of open PR’s decrease in size” ?

That ensures that larger or trickier PRs are left open for longer :(
I've basically failed to incorporate reviews into my workflow, though @pnkfelix and I co-scheduled some "let's sit on a call and review things in silence" time :)
so that may change
I would like to increase the amount of time I use for that, but it's always a balancing act
I think we should always be looking for ways to recognize and reward people who review PRs
which is easy to say

nikomatsakis said:

I've basically failed to incorporate reviews into my workflow, though pnkfelix and I co-scheduled some "let's sit on a call and review things in silence" time :)

/me failed at the “silence” part of that
What are the steps to get review rights for Rust? I'd be happy to help with reviews where I can, although I probably need a bit more knowledge about rustc first.
The steps are: write PRs, participate, and do "non-binding" reviews

also, scheduling 1:1 synchronous time to review things with the author is a pattern I've seen help with this. forces you to stay focused, gives you space to ask larger "structural" questions, and provides time pressure
and bother @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser :)
ah that reminds me:
I have these calendly slots: https://calendly.com/nikomatsakis/

tmandry said:

I think we should always be looking for ways to recognize and reward people who review PRs

It kind of makes sense to credit the reviewer as much as the PR author, although I don't know how to actually do that.
if there's anything blocked on a review for me, please feel free to snag one
and we can walk over the review together

eholk said:

It kind of makes sense to credit the reviewer as much as the PR author, although I don't know how to actually do that.

paging optopodi @Esteban Küber ;)

I probably need a bit more knowledge about rustc first.

I've found that there's enough volume of "trivial" PRs (no deep knowledge needed) that can be taken on. Once you have reviewer permissions we rely on you being scared enough of not reviewing things you don't understand and reassign if that's the case :sweat_smile:

It kind of makes sense to credit the reviewer as much as the PR author, although I don't know how to actually do that.

paging optopodi

I was all :eyes: on my end when reading that :sweat_smile:

tmandry said:

I think we should always be looking for ways to recognize and reward people who review PRs

maybe by shifting team membership criteria a bit?
or making that another path
@triagebot end-topic okay I think we can move on now

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
I'm still concerned about "diffusion of responsibility": if you have multiple people marked as reviewers, we can all go "the other person will take it".
I heard Nell Shamrell-Harrington say that she counts reviewing as a coding activity, which I think is a cool way to think of it.

Esteban Küber said:

I'm still concerned about "diffusion of responsibility": if you have multiple people marked as reviewers, we can all go "the other person will take it".

yeah. code ownership models can maybe help with that
GitHub should have a review leaderboard for projects in the contributors section
Could add it to thanks.rust-lang

GitHub should have a review leaderboard for projects in the contributors section

I've been thinking about doing that with optopodi, but I'm shy of putting people on blast...
I want to say we incorporate reviewers into thanks.rust-lang.org, but we don't call them out specifically
maybe I'm being too cautious.
Okay, this is an interesting discussion but a little beyond the scope of the meeting. Maybe a good topic for a t-compiler steering meeting?
yes
Alright
don’t know who would drive writing the doc, but yes
I guess I’m the one to blame for bringing up the broader issue. :)
It's certainly a topic I'm interested in but I don't think I can confidently promise to do it right now :) and happy if someone else wants to
moving on
Polish issues
Let's take time to update the upcoming sprint section of the doc with our polish issues (including carryovers)
i’m sorry, can someone point me at the project board? I’m having trouble figuring out which github repo it is associated with.
https://github.com/orgs/rust-lang/projects/2
oh I see, its not associated with any specific repo
(I made it an org project so we could put issues from both rust and wg-async-foundations repos)
but yeah, it makes it harder to find
(IMHO github should autolink it from repo X when one adds issues from X)
am I correct that there are currently only two unclaimed polish issues?
or maybe three, hold on
I'm seeing 13
not all 13 are tagged as Polish
true, I'm not sure if we should be using that label as a filter @eholk?
oh is that label not necessarily kept up to date? Okay
For now the On Deck column on the board is the best source. I'm working on tagging everything as AsyncAwait-Polish too, but right now that's incomplete.

BTW, just got reminded of something that I wanted to highlight: A PR landed on nightly last week (or the one before?) that prints out associated types for futures:

20 |     demand_is_send(get_foo())
   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ lifetime mismatch
   |
   = note: expected opaque type `impl futures::Future<Output = [async output]>`
              found opaque type `impl futures::Future<Output = [async output]>`

So now you'll see things "expected impl Future<Output = ()> found impl Future<Output = i32>".
that's amazing
I guess we could do it for any trait
@triagebot end-topic also I think most people are done?

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
Sprint goals
Okay, now let's do the rest of the sprint!
I do think @tmandry we should take a general goal of "year end blog post"
I'm ok to "take the lead" on authoring it
and you can edit/revise
presuming you are short of time what with your many hats
but i'm also ok to not do that :)
I mean, I would love to write it, though being apprehensive about time is a good default position
I mean I should be paranoid too :)
I guess whoever has time first should do it
yes, sg
regarding async fundamentals: I feel like we should keep our focus on dyn
I would like to get to the point where we have ... something :) a blog post of some kind of initial proposal? is that plausible?
When do you want the post to go out, niko?
not sure :) late this year or early next year? :)
(for eoy summary, but I guess it goes for dyn as well)
oh, also, I meant to point out earlier that the next sprint meeting would be Dec 23rd, two days before Christmas
I'll actually be working that day (I start vacation dec 24)
I love the hand-wavy "Q4/Q1" niko :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
If everything goes well I'll be moving on the 23rd :skull:
in fact I will be on a plane at the time of the meeting
seems likely though that we should skip?
if folks still want to meet I'm happy to have someone else run the meeting
but.. yeah, seems likely
I think we should probably still treat it more or less as a normal two week sprint, given the holidays
should we try to “just” reschedule to a day earlier?
well, I guess we can all just factor in any vacation we'll be taking
I know that’s non-trivial given everyone’s standing meetings schedules etc
I'd be ok to run the meeting
it's possible I could do it 24 hours earlier, fwiw
I'll be out starting the 21st, but I'll update my portions of the planning doc beforehand.
the 24 hour earlier time slot is available for me. Not sure about everyone else. But maybe its simplest to “just” have niko run the meeting instead.
I could do 24 hour earlier as well
but I'm generally opposed to altering schedules :)
ON PRINCIPLE
THE SHOW MEETING MUST GO ON
ok, maybe getting a bit punchy now
well if enough people can do 24 hours earlier I'd be up for that
but I'll note that the following two weeks (for me) probably won't involve a lot of progress
sounds right
let's move it!

nikomatsakis said:

I would like to get to the point where we have ... something :) a blog post of some kind of initial proposal? is that plausible?

I think right now we're juggling two possible futures and it might be that we need to present that, if we can't synthesize them ourselves
select!
work it into the blog post title!
ah, very nice :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
sounds right

nikomatsakis said:

let's move it!

okay, done
we're running low on time
where can I find the latest on the dyn(er) stuff?
nowhere really
which is why we need to write a blog post or something
there is some code etc
but I don't think it would be understandable
maybe a hackmd would be less pressure than a blog post?
@nikomatsakis what about RPITIT and naming function outputs, is there anything we need to do there?
hmm. yes.
sad if personal blog posts are high pressure
I don't see a blog post as higher pressure
though I say that knowing that I go nuts on my own blog posts
it's more like: the work of coallescing the design
anyway @Nick Cameron happy to do a 1:1 to talk thing sthrough too
could be useful
or just a group chat

tmandry said:

nikomatsakis what about RPITIT and naming function outputs, is there anything we need to do there?

two things
(1) @Santiago Pastorino is working on impl, not sure what's a good goal to put
(2) I want to withdraw the RFC I had and open a new one, I think?
with edits?
also I really enjoy saying "RPITIT"
Do you think it's realistic to hope to post a new one in the next two weeks?
I do, actually
okay
added those
The other part of that, I realize, is that it "connects" somewhat to some of the specialization discussion
but I will leave that out of any rfc :)
more blog posts perhaps
anyway, I think that's a good goal for EOY
great
okay we're out of time and I have to go
I guess in the interest of consistency I'll post everything in the doc here, folks are welcome to ask follow up questions etc.

Sprint goals

General

  • [ ] (nikomatsakis/tmandry) year end blog post summarizing async wg state

Async fundamentals

  • [ ] Post proposal/outline for dyn strategy: "A tale of two dyns"
  • [ ] Make RPIT use a type alias to a type defined in body's function
  • [ ] Post a new RFC incorporating RPITIT and naming function output types

Async iteration

Goals:

  • [ ] Publish blogpost for chances to proc macro
    • don't need sigils for disambiguation (for some cases)
    • alternatives for operation of ?
  • [ ] Blogpost exploring size_hint
  • [ ] Add rustc_generator attribute to annotate fns as a placeholder to uplift logic from proc-macro
  • [ ] Add ItemKind::Generator or a new field on functions in type system, with no new syntax
  • [ ] Stretch goal: start experimenting with for await pat in expr in proc-macro

Polish

Goals:

  • [ ] Create a list of confusing error message issues for the error messages goal (carry over from last sprint)
  • [ ] Update must not suspend lint page to reflect current status (carry over from last sprint)

Issues: ([project board])

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) Strange async use ...; compiler suggestion #87613
    - [ ] extend Rust parser with use injection point(s) to drive suggestions

  • [ ] (tmandry) E0623 highlights wrong parameter in async fn #74256
    - [ ] Put up an initial PR and get a first review
    - [ ] Draft PR for follow-up fixes (or roll them into the same one)

  • [ ] (nikomatsakis) pick "Async fn does not compile if lifetime does not appear in bounds (sometimes)" #63033 back up again
    - plan is to experiment with "intersection lifetimes"

  • [ ] [#89734] Unhelpful compiler message when a reference is used inside of an await block #723120 (estebank)
    finish review and land

  • [ ] (eholk) error[E0391]: cycle detected when computing type of async fn #78649
    - [ ] Investigate to find root cause

  • [ ] (eholk) Dropped variables still included in generator type #57478 (part of #69663)
    - [ ] Wait on and respond to code review feedback
    - [ ] Land it

Portability across runtimes

  • [ ] (nrc) consider async fns vs poll_read/write for AsyncRead/AsyncWrite traits
  • [ ] (nrc) discuss two trait alternative to RFC 2930 with someone?
  • [ ] (nrc, stretch goal) (possibly to replace the above) create some kind of WG to discuss reading into uninit memory issues with so that we can get things moving a little quicker in the non-async space

Tooling

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) update roadmap to point to https://github.com/rust-lang/async-crashdump-debugging-initiative
  • [ ] (pnkfelix) post tokio-console 0.x crates to crates.io
  • [ ] (pnkfelix) revisit original non-responsiveness issue to see if it was resolved
Thanks so much everyone, see you in.. 13 days :)
Thanks @tmandry!
heh, I find blog posts high pressure - I feel like it is on the record once its in the blog :-)

nikomatsakis said:

anyway Nick Cameron happy to do a 1:1 to talk thing sthrough too

I'd be glad to, either 1:1 or group whichever you think is more useful
